title: List of heads of state of Sudan - Wikipedia
snippet: Lieutenant-General Ahmed Awad Ibn ... Fattah al-Burhan. The Transitional Military Council was replaced with the Transitional Sovereignty Council on 21 August 2019, under the chairmanship of al-Burhan....

title: Power Relations in Sudan after the Fall of Bashir - Stiftung Wissenschaft und Politik
snippet: Perhaps the most profound change in Sudan’s politi­cal system was the rise of the RSF to become one of the two most powerful armed forces in the country, whose leadership simultaneously controlled a large part of the economy and exercised significant politi­cal influence.

title: SUDAN’S LEADERSHIP RESHUFFLE: SOMETHING BETTER OR MORE OF THE SAME? - Sudan Democracy First Group
snippet: The resignation of Ali Osman Taha and Nafi Ali Nafi from government, who were competing to succeed Bashir, opens the door for an even larger change. The departure of a large group of the leaders of the Islamist Movement from government – an almost synchronized departure – is alluding to a final divorce between the Movement and the party/regime, which was a demand of many of its own reformist cadres, such as the Sai’hoon. In conclusion, strategic concerns surrounding Sudan, whether internal or external, will remain unaffected by the leadership reshuffle.

title: Abdel Fattah al-Burhan - Wikipedia
snippet: Following the Sudanese Revolution in April 2019, he was handed control of the military junta, the Transitional Military Council, a day after it was formed, due to protesters' dissatisfaction with the establishment ties of initial leader Ahmed Awad Ibn Auf.

title: Putting Sudan’s Political Transition Back on Track | United States Institute of Peace
snippet: On October 25, the military, in a familiar move, seized power throwing into question the political transition that would result in civilian rule. The civilian cabinet was dissolved, its leaders arrested and a state of emergency declared.
